misconceptions.name: Solved wrong problem (distance between points instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points in 2D space instead of reading a single numeric grade (0–100) and converting it to a letter grade using conditional ranges. The submission does not address any of the specified grade-calculator requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads coordinates of two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and then, using conditionals, print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified numeric ranges.
symptoms: Program asks for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
Four double inputs are read instead of one numeric grade.
The code computes dx, dy, and uses Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy) instead of any conditional logic for grade ranges.
No conditional statements or output related to letter grades (A, B, C, D, F) appear in the program.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have misinterpreted or confused the assignment prompt with a different problem (distance between two points), indicating a misunderstanding of the problem requirements rather than a small coding mistake.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate in your own words what inputs are required and what outputs are expected. Then design an if-else chain (or equivalent) that checks the numeric grade against the given ranges and prints the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using conditionals
Program design based on a specification
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around computing the distance between two points, with no code that reads or processes a numeric grade or outputs a letter grade, so it clearly does not implement the required grade calculator.

evidence.note: All input and computation logic is dedicated to reading coordinates and computing distance; there is no grade input or letter-grade logic as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete program to calculate the distance between two points, a solution entirely unrelated to the requirement of implementing a Grade Calculator using conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have solved an unrelated problem (Distance Between Points) and submitted it for the Grade Calculator question (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements (if/else) to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code asks for four coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Code calculates distance using Math.sqrt()
No conditional logic (if/else) for grading is present
Final output is a numerical distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly identify or read the problem description for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the requirements for Question 3 (Grade Calculator) and ensure the submitted code implements the grade calculation logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is a complete solution to a different, well-known geometric problem (Distance formula). It contains none of the logic required for the Grade Calculator task.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinate variables instead of a single numeric grade.
The core calculation performs the distance formula, not grade determination based on conditional ranges, indicating the wrong problem was solved.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output reports a numerical distance, not a letter grade which was the required output for Q3.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator program. This shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program to calculate the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires writing a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade
Program calculates distance using Euclidean formula instead of comparing grade ranges
Output shows distance calculation instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade range checking
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misinterpretation of the assignment requirements. The student may have confused this assignment with a different problem or failed to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task requires: (1) Reading a single numeric grade input, (2) Using conditional statements (if/else) to check which range the grade falls into, (3) Outputting the corresponding letter grade. Start fresh with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the grade calculator problem. It calculates distance between points with completely different inputs, logic, and output. This is not a minor implementation error but a fundamental misalignment with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: Student is reading coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade value

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);

    System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Program calculates and outputs distance instead of determining and outputting a letter grade

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted problem as distance calculation instead of grade classification
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) instead of writing a grade calculator that classifies a single numeric grade into A–F based on given ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates for two points and outputs the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, use conditional statements to determine which letter grade range (A–F) it belongs to, and then print that letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
No conditional logic on the input value; only arithmetic and Math.sqrt are used.
Output is a numeric distance, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements, possibly mixing it up with a different assignment about computing the distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and identify the required input(s), the processing (logic/conditions), and the exact required output format. Then design your program specifically around classifying a single numeric grade into a letter grade.
related_concepts: Translating requirements into input, processing, and output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (variable names, prompts, math formula, and final print statement) matches the distance-between-points problem and has no elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: The program reads four doubles as coordinates, computes dx and dy, then uses the distance formula and prints the distance, with no reference to a numeric grade or letter grades.
